title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: first load mixgb package nhanes3_newborn dataset, contains 16 variables various types (integer/numeric/factor/ordinal factor). 9 variables missing values. impute dataset, first need set Mixgb imputer choice settings leave default. Note need convert data dgCMatrix one-hot coding format. package convert automatically. Variables following types: numeric, integer, factor ordinal factor. Except data, arguments Mixgb$new( ) either hyperparameters verbose settings XGBoost training.
code: library(mixgb) data(nhanes3_newborn) str(nhanes3_newborn) #> tibble [2,107 × 16] (S3: tbl_df/tbl/data.frame) #>  $ HSHSIZER: int [1:2107] 4 3 5 4 4 3 5 3 3 3 ... #>  $ HSAGEIR : int [1:2107] 2 5 10 10 8 3 10 7 2 7 ... #>  $ HSSEX   : Factor w/ 2 levels "1","2": 2 1 2 2 1 1 2 2 2 1 ... #>  $ DMARACER: Factor w/ 3 levels "1","2","3": 1 1 2 1 1 1 2 1 2 2 ... #>  $ DMAETHNR: Factor w/ 3 levels "1","2","3": 3 1 3 3 3 3 3 3 3 3 ... #>  $ DMARETHN: Factor w/ 4 levels "1","2","3","4": 1 3 2 1 1 1 2 1 2 2 ... #>  $ BMPHEAD : num [1:2107] 39.3 45.4 43.9 45.8 44.9 42.2 45.8 NA 40.2 44.5 ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "Head circumference (cm)" #>  $ BMPRECUM: num [1:2107] 59.5 69.2 69.8 73.8 69 61.7 74.8 NA 64.5 70.2 ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "Recumbent length (cm)" #>  $ BMPSB1  : num [1:2107] 8.2 13 6 8 8.2 9.4 5.2 NA 7 5.9 ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "First subscapular skinfold (mm)" #>  $ BMPSB2  : num [1:2107] 8 13 5.6 10 7.8 8.4 5.2 NA 7 5.4 ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "Second subscapular skinfold (mm)" #>  $ BMPTR1  : num [1:2107] 9 15.6 7 16.4 9.8 9.6 5.8 NA 11 6.8 ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "First triceps skinfold (mm)" #>  $ BMPTR2  : num [1:2107] 9.4 14 8.2 12 8.8 8.2 6.6 NA 10.9 7.6 ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "Second triceps skinfold (mm)" #>  $ BMPWT   : num [1:2107] 6.35 9.45 7.15 10.7 9.35 7.15 8.35 NA 7.35 8.65 ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "Weight (kg)" #>  $ DMPPIR  : num [1:2107] 3.186 1.269 0.416 2.063 1.464 ... #>   ..- attr(*, "label")= chr "Poverty income ratio" #>  $ HFF1    : Factor w/ 2 levels "1","2": 2 2 1 1 1 2 2 1 2 1 ... #>  $ HYD1    : Ord.factor w/ 5 levels "1"<"2"<"3"<"4"<..: 1 3 1 1 1 1 1 1 2 1 ... colSums(is.na(nhanes3_newborn)) #> HSHSIZER  HSAGEIR    HSSEX DMARACER DMAETHNR DMARETHN  BMPHEAD BMPRECUM  #>        0        0        0        0        0        0      124      114  #>   BMPSB1   BMPSB2   BMPTR1   BMPTR2    BMPWT   DMPPIR     HFF1     HYD1  #>      161      169      124      167      117      192        7        0 #default MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = nhanes3_newborn)  #with chosen settings params = list(max_depth = 6,                gamma = 0.1,                eta = 0.3,                min_child_weight = 1,                subsample = 1,                colsample_bytree = 1,                colsample_bylevel = 1,                colsample_bynode=1,                nthread = 4,                tree_method = "auto",                gpu_id = 0,                predictor = "auto")  MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = nhanes3_newborn, xgb.params = params, nrounds = 100, early_stopping_rounds = 1, print_every_n = 1, verbose = 0)

title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: Imputation performance can affected Hyperparameters settings. may seems daunting tune large set hyperparameters, time, can narrow search many hyperparameters correlated. default nrounds value XGBoost users need specify . package mixgb, set default nrounds 50. However, recommend users use mixgb_cv() find optimal nrounds first. default, mixgb_cv() randomly choose incomplete variable response build XGBoost model variables using complete cases dataset. Therefore, run mixgb_cv() likely return different results. Users can also specify response covariates argument response select_covariates, respectively. Since results returned mixgb_cv() mostly less 20, ’ll set nrounds = 20 imputer. now use imputer obtain m imputed datasets, stored list m data tables. m = 1, single imputation undertaken. Users can also specify number imputation iterations maxit. can also customise imputation settings: Whether use bootstrapping types predictive mean matching number donors predictive mean matching Whether convert ordinal factors integer ( imputation process faster) Initial imputation methods

title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: dataset decent amount ordinal factors, imputation process speed convert integers. nhanes3_newborn data, one ordinal factor, can still see imputation time smaller ordinalAsInteger = TRUE. m maxit larger, difference even obvious. Note ordinalAsInteger = TRUE , class ordinal factors imputed datasets also integer. recommend use default PMM setting pmm.type = "auto", impute numeric integer variables PMM (type 2) impute categorical variables without PMM. don’t apply PMM integer variables, missing values may imputed numeric. Sometimes can problematic, especially integers actually converted ordinal factors. Therefore, pmm.type = NULL disabled ordinalAsInteger = TRUE . imputing, can look imputed values variable interest. example, 5 imputed sets missing values variable BMPHEAD.
code: system.time(imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1,ordinalAsInteger = FALSE)) #> mixgb with bootstrap: imputing set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4 -- 5 #>    user  system elapsed  #>   6.683   0.988   6.202  system.time(imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1,ordinalAsInteger = TRUE)) #> mixgb with bootstrap: imputing set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4 -- 5 #>    user  system elapsed  #>   6.284   0.980   5.907 imputed.BMPHEAD<-imputed_var(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.name = "BMPHEAD", original.data = nhanes3_newborn) imputed.BMPHEAD #>        m1   m2   m3   m4   m5 #>   1: 43.8 41.6 41.0 43.8 42.0 #>   2: 41.8 42.1 39.9 41.3 39.2 #>   3: 43.2 42.8 43.8 43.2 43.2 #>   4: 43.2 42.0 42.7 42.8 40.9 #>   5: 46.2 46.2 45.2 46.1 45.9 #>  ---                          #> 120: 46.0 45.6 46.0 44.1 44.0 #> 121: 44.8 42.8 45.5 45.9 47.3 #> 122: 41.8 40.3 39.5 42.1 42.9 #> 123: 42.7 42.6 43.8 43.9 43.8 #> 124: 41.0 44.5 43.9 46.1 43.0

what: Impute new unseen data using a trained imputer
title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: First can split nhanes3_newborn dataset training data test data. can use training data obtain m imputed datasets save imputation models. achieve , users need set save.models = TRUE. default save.vars = NULL, imputation models variables missing data training data saved. However, unseen data may also missing values variables, comprehensive save models variables setting save.vars = colnames(train.data). Note take much longer time need train save model variable. users confident certain variables missing values new data, recommend specify names indices variables save.vars instead saving models variables. can extract m imputed datasets saved imputer object $imputed.data. impute new data saved imputer object, use impute_new() function. User can also specify whether use new data initial imputation. default, initial.newdata = FALSE, use information training data initially impute new data. New data imputed saved models. process considerably fast don’t need build imputation models . PMM used trained imputer, predicted values missing entries new dataset matched training data. Users can also set number donors PMM imputing new data. default, pmm.k = NULL , means setting training object used. Similarly, users can set number imputed datasets m. Note value smaller equal one set trained imputer. specified, use m value trained imputer.
code: set.seed(2022) n <- nrow(nhanes3_newborn) idx <- sample(1:n, size = round(0.7 * n), replace = FALSE) train.data <- nhanes3_newborn[idx, ] test.data <- nhanes3_newborn[-idx, ] MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = train.data) mixgb.obj <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1, save.models = TRUE, save.vars = NULL) #> mixgb with bootstrap: saving models and imputing set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4 -- 5 imputed.traindata <- mixgb.obj$imputed.data #the 5th imputed dataset head(imputed.traindata[[5]]) #>    HSHSIZER HSAGEIR HSSEX DMARACER DMAETHNR DMARETHN BMPHEAD BMPRECUM BMPSB1 #> 1:        7       2     1        1        1        3    42.4     66.7    7.8 #> 2:        4       3     2        2        3        2    42.6     67.1    8.8 #> 3:        3       9     2        2        3        2    46.5     64.3    8.6 #> 4:        3       9     2        1        3        1    46.2     68.5   10.8 #> 5:        5       4     1        1        3        1    44.7     63.0    6.0 #> 6:        5      10     1        1        3        1    45.2     72.0    5.4 #>    BMPSB2 BMPTR1 BMPTR2 BMPWT DMPPIR HFF1 HYD1 #> 1:    8.0    8.8    9.5  7.60  1.701    2    1 #> 2:    8.8   13.3   12.2  8.70  0.102    2    1 #> 3:    8.0   10.4    9.2  8.00  0.359    1    3 #> 4:   10.0   16.6   16.0  8.98  0.561    1    3 #> 5:    5.8    9.0    9.0  7.60  2.379    2    1 #> 6:    5.4    9.2    9.4  9.00  2.173    2    2 imputed.testdata <- impute_new(object = mixgb.obj, newdata = test.data)  #> Imputing new data with mixgb:  set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4 -- 5 imputed.testdata <- impute_new(object = mixgb.obj, newdata = test.data, initial.newdata = FALSE, pmm.k = 3, m = 4) #> Imputing new data with mixgb:  set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4

title: Authors and Citation
text: Yongshi Deng. Author, maintainer. Thomas Lumley. Thesis advisor.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Deng Y (2022). mixgb: Multiple Imputation XGBoost. https://github.com/agnesdeng/mixgb, https://agnesdeng.github.io/mixgb/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost},   author = {Yongshi Deng},   year = {2022},   note = {https://github.com/agnesdeng/mixgb, https://agnesdeng.github.io/mixgb/}, }

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: mixgb: multiple imputation XGBoost Mixgb scalable multiple imputation framework based XGBoost, bootstrapping predictive mean matching. proposed framework implemented R package mixgb. shown framework obtains less biased estimates reflects appropriate imputation variability, achieving high computational efficiency. details, please check paper https://arxiv.org/abs/2106.01574. (package revised updated since preprint posted. Simulation code original supplementary files may run expected. Revised paper adapted code updated soon.)

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: Currently users can set XGBoost parameter nthread multithreading OpenMP support. However, MacOS disabled OpenMP support.

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: User can now set different number iterations maxit. single multiple imputation XGBoost can predictive mean matching Bootstrap data make m imputations optional. User can set bootstrap = FALSE disable bootstrap. Users can also set sampling related hyperparameters XGBoost (subsample, colsample_bytree, colsample_bylevel, colsample_bynode) less 1 achieve similar effect. Add predicted mean matching type 0. Now options pmm.type NULL,0,1,2or“auto” `(type 2 numeric/integer variables, PMM categorical variables. Added validation checks Compatible data.table enhance speed Cross-validation pre-tune nrounds

text: make m imputation parallel pre-tune hyperparameters Visualisation imputed data

what: Data cleaning before feeding in the imputer
title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: highly recommended clean check data feeding imputer. common issues: Data data frame. ID removed Missing values coded NA NaN Inf -Inf allowed Empty cells coded NA sensible values Variables “character” type converted “factor” instead Variables “factor” type least two levels function data_clean() can preliminary check fix obvious problems. However, fix issues related data quality.
code: cleanWithNA.df<-data_clean(rawdata)

what: Example: Imputing missing values with mixgb
title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: first load mixgb package nhanes3_newborn dataset, contains 16 variables various types (integer/numeric/factor/ordinal factor). 9 variables missing values. impute dataset, first need set Mixgb imputer choice settings leave default. Note need convert data dgCMatrix one-hot coding format. package convert automatically. Variables following types: numeric, integer, factor ordinal factor. Except data, arguments Mixgb$new( ) either hyperparameters verbose settings XGBoost training. ###Tuning hyperparameters Imputation performance can affected Hyperparameters settings. may seems daunting tune large set hyperparameters, time, can narrow search many hyperparameters correlated. default nrounds value XGBoost users need specify . package mixgb, set default nrounds 50. However, recommend users use mixgb_cv() find optimal nrounds first. default, mixgb_cv() randomly choose incomplete variable response build XGBoost model variables using complete cases dataset. Therefore, run mixgb_cv() likely return different results. Users can also specify response covariates argument response select_covariates, respectively. Since results returned mixgb_cv() mostly less 20, ’ll set nrounds = 20 imputer. now use imputer obtain m imputed datasets, stored list m data tables. m = 1, single imputation undertaken. Users can also specify number imputation iterations maxit. can also customise imputation settings: Whether use bootstrapping types predictive mean matching number donors predictive mean matching Whether convert ordinal factors integer ( imputation process faster) Initial imputation methods
code: data(nhanes3_newborn) str(nhanes3_newborn) colSums(is.na(nhanes3_newborn)) #default MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = nhanes3_newborn)  #with chosen settings params = list(max_depth = 6,                gamma = 0.1,                eta = 0.3,                min_child_weight = 1,                subsample = 1,                colsample_bytree = 1,                colsample_bylevel = 1,                colsample_bynode=1,                nthread = 4,                tree_method = "auto",                gpu_id = 0,                predictor = "auto")  MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = nhanes3_newborn, xgb.params = params, nrounds = 100, early_stopping_rounds = 1, print_every_n = 1, verbose = 0) optimal.nrounds <- mixgb_cv(data = nhanes3_newborn, verbose = FALSE) optimal.nrounds$evaluation.log optimal.nrounds$best.nrounds optimal.nrounds <- mixgb_cv(data = nhanes3_newborn, nfold = 10, nrounds = 100, early_stopping_rounds = 1, response = "BMPHEAD",                               select_covariates = c("HSHSIZER","HSAGEIR", "HSSEX", "DMARETHN", "BMPRECUM", "BMPSB1", "BMPSB2",                               "BMPTR1", "BMPTR2"  , "BMPWT", "DMPPIR", "HFF1", "HYD1"),verbose = FALSE) optimal.nrounds$best.nrounds MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = nhanes3_newborn, nrounds = 20) imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1) imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1,  bootstrap = TRUE,                              pmm.type = "auto", pmm.k = 5,                               ordinalAsInteger = TRUE,                             initial.num = "normal", initial.int = "sample", initial.fac = "mode")

previous_headings: Example: Imputing missing values with mixgb
title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: dataset decent amount ordinal factors, imputation process speed convert integers. nhanes3_newborn data, one ordinal factor, can still see imputation time smaller ordinalAsInteger = TRUE. m maxit larger, difference even obvious. Note ordinalAsInteger = TRUE , class ordinal factors imputed datasets also integer. recommend use default PMM setting pmm.type = "auto", impute numeric integer variables PMM (type 2) impute categorical variables without PMM. don’t apply PMM integer variables, missing values may imputed numeric. Sometimes can problematic, especially integers actually converted ordinal factors. Therefore, pmm.type = NULL disabled ordinalAsInteger = TRUE .
code: system.time(imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1,ordinalAsInteger = FALSE))  system.time(imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1,ordinalAsInteger = TRUE))

previous_headings: Example: Imputing missing values with mixgb
title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: imputing, can look imputed values variable interest. example, 5 imputed sets missing values variable BMPHEAD.
code: imputed.BMPHEAD<-imputed_var(imputation.list = imputed.data, var.name = "BMPHEAD", original.data = nhanes3_newborn) imputed.BMPHEAD

what: Example: Impute new unseen data using a trained imputer
title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: First can split nhanes3_newborn dataset training data test data. can use training data obtain m imputed datasets save imputation models. achieve , users need set save.models = TRUE. default save.vars = NULL, imputation models variables missing data training data saved. However, unseen data may also missing values variables, comprehensive save models variables setting save.vars = colnames(train.data). Note take much longer time need train save model variable. users confident certain variables missing values new data, recommend specify names indices variables save.vars instead saving models variables. can extract m imputed datasets saved imputer object $imputed.data. impute new data saved imputer object, use impute_new() function. User can also specify whether use new data initial imputation. default, initial.newdata = FALSE, use information training data initially impute new data. New data imputed saved models. process considerably fast don’t need build imputation models . PMM used trained imputer, predicted values missing entries new dataset matched training data. Users can also set number donors PMM imputing new data. default, pmm.k = NULL , means setting training object used. Similarly, users can set number imputed datasets m. Note value smaller equal one set trained imputer. specified, use m value trained imputer.
code: set.seed(2022) n <- nrow(nhanes3_newborn) idx <- sample(1:n, size = round(0.7 * n), replace = FALSE) train.data <- nhanes3_newborn[idx, ] test.data <- nhanes3_newborn[-idx, ] MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = train.data) mixgb.obj <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, maxit = 1, save.models = TRUE, save.vars = NULL) imputed.traindata <- mixgb.obj$imputed.data #the 5th imputed dataset head(imputed.traindata[[5]]) imputed.testdata <- impute_new(object = mixgb.obj, newdata = test.data) imputed.testdata <- impute_new(object = mixgb.obj, newdata = test.data, initial.newdata = FALSE, pmm.k = 3, m = 4)

title: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost
text: Multiple imputation can run GPU support machines NVIDIA GPUs. Note users install R package xgboost GPU support first. xgboost R package pre-built binary Linux x86_64 GPU supportcan downloaded release page https://github.com/dmlc/xgboost/releases/tag/v1.4.0 package can installed running following commands: users can install package mixgb R. Users just need specify tree_method = "gpu_list" params list setting Mixgb imputer. GPU-realted arguments include gpu_id predictor. default, gpu_id = 0 predictor = "auto".
code: # Install dependencies $ R -q -e "install.packages(c('data.table', 'jsonlite'))"  # Install XGBoost $ R CMD INSTALL ./xgboost_r_gpu_linux.tar.gz devtools::install_github("agnesdeng/mixgb") library(mixgb) params = list(max_depth = 6,                gamma = 0.1,                eta = 0.3,                min_child_weight = 1,                subsample = 1,                colsample_bytree = 1,                colsample_bylevel = 1,                colsample_bynode=1,                nthread = 4,                tree_method='gpu_list',                gpu_id = 0,                predictor = "auto")                MIXGB<-Mixgb$new(withNA.df,xgb.params = params)  mixgb.data<-MIXGB$impute(m=5)

XGBoost training stop validation performance improved k rounds. print_every_n Print XGBoost evaluation information every nth iteration verbose > 0. verbose Verbose setting XGBoost training.

title: XGBoost imputer: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — Mixgb
code: Mixgb$new(   data,   xgb.params = list(max_depth = 6, gamma = 0.1, eta = 0.3, min_child_weight = 1,     subsample = 1, colsample_bytree = 1, colsample_bylevel = 1, colsample_bynode = 1,     nthread = 4, tree_method = "auto", gpu_id = 0, predictor = "auto"),   nrounds = 50,   early_stopping_rounds = 10,   print_every_n = 10L,   verbose = 0 )

title: XGBoost imputer: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — Mixgb
text: data data.frame data.table missing values xgb.params list XGBoost hyperparameters. nrounds maximum number boosting iterations XGBoost. Default: 50 early_stopping_rounds integer value k. XGBoost training stop validation performance improved k rounds. Default: 10. print_every_n Print XGBoost evaluation information every nth iteration verbose > 0. verbose Verbose setting XGBoost training: 0 (silent), 1 (print information) 2 (print additional information). Default: 0

title: XGBoost imputer: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — Mixgb
text: XGBoost imputer object chosen hyperparameters verbose options

title: XGBoost imputer: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — Mixgb
text: Impute missing values pre-set XGBoost imputer obtain multiply imputed datasets, option save models imputing new data later .

title: XGBoost imputer: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — Mixgb
code: Mixgb$impute(   m = 5,   maxit = 1,   bootstrap = TRUE,   pmm.type = "auto",   pmm.k = 5,   pmm.link = "prob",   ordinalAsInteger = TRUE,   initial.num = "normal",   initial.int = "mode",   initial.fac = "mode",   save.models = FALSE,   save.vars = NULL,   ... )

title: XGBoost imputer: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — Mixgb
text: m number imputed datasets. Default: 5 maxit number imputation iterations. Default: 1 bootstrap Whether use bootstrapping multiple imputation. default, bootstrap = TRUE. FALSE, users recommended specify sampling-related hyperparameters XGBoost obtain imputations adequate variability. pmm.type types predictive mean matching (PMM). Possible values: NULL: Imputations without PMM; 0: Imputations PMM type 0; 1: Imputations PMM type 1; 2: Imputations PMM type 2; "auto" (Default): Imputations PMM type 2 numeric/integer variables; imputations without PMM categorical variables. pmm.k number donors predictive mean matching. Default: 5 pmm.link link predictive mean matching binary variables "prob" (Default): use probabilities; "logit": use logit values. ordinalAsInteger Whether convert ordinal factors integers. default setting ordinalAsInteger = TRUE can speed imputation process. initial.num Initial imputation method numeric type data: "normal" (Default); "mean"; "median"; "mode"; "sample". initial.int Initial imputation method integer type data: "mode" (Default); "sample". initial.fac Initial imputation method factor type data: "mode" (Default); "sample". save.models Whether save models imputing new data later . Default: FALSE save.vars Response models variables specified save.vars saved imputing new data. Can vector names indices. default, save.vars = NULL, response models variables missing values saved. save models, please specify save.vars = colnames(data). ... Extra arguments pass XGBoost

title: XGBoost imputer: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — Mixgb
text: save.models = FALSE, return list m imputed datasets. save.models = TRUE, return object imputed datasets, saved models parameters.

title: XGBoost imputer: Multiple imputation through XGBoost — Mixgb
code: #use default MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = nhanes3_newborn) #obtain m multiply datasets without saving models imputed.data <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5) #> mixgb with bootstrap: imputing set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4 -- 5  #obtain m multiply imputed datasets and save models for imputing new data later on imputed.obj <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, save.models = TRUE) #> mixgb with bootstrap: saving models and imputing set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4 -- 5

what: Create missing values for a dataset — createNA

text: function creates missing values missing complete random mechanism (MCAR). demonstration purposes .

title: Create missing values for a dataset — createNA
code: createNA(data, names = NULL, p = 0.3, seed = NULL)

title: Create missing values for a dataset — createNA
text: data complete data frame. names names variables missing values generated. p proportion missing values data frame proportions missing values corresponding variables specified names. seed integer value. Default: NULL

title: Create missing values for a dataset — createNA
text: data frame artificial missing values

title: Create missing values for a dataset — createNA
code: # Create 30% MCAR data across all variables in a dataset withNA.df <- createNA(iris, p = 0.3)  # Create 30% MCAR data in a specified variable in a dataset withNA.df <- createNA(iris, names = c("Sepal.Length"), p = 0.3)  # Create MCAR data in several specified variables in a dataset withNA.df <- createNA(iris, names = c("Sepal.Length", "Petal.Width", "Species"),                       p = c(0.3, 0.2, 0.1))

title: Impute new data with a saved mixgb imputer object — impute_new
text: object saved imputer object created $impute() newdata data.frame data.table. New data missing values. initial.newdata Whether use information new data initially impute new data. default, set FALSE, original data passed MIXGB$new() used initial imputation. pmm.k number donors predictive mean matching. NULL (defualt), pmm.k value saved imputer object used. m number imputed datasets. NULL (defualt), m value saved imputer object used.

title: Impute new data with a saved mixgb imputer object — impute_new
code: set.seed(2022) n <- nrow(nhanes3_newborn) idx <- sample(1:n, size = round(0.7 * n), replace = FALSE) train.data <- nhanes3_newborn[idx, ] test.data <- nhanes3_newborn[-idx, ]  MIXGB <- Mixgb$new(data = train.data) imputed.obj <- MIXGB$impute(m = 5, bootstrap = TRUE, save.models = TRUE) #> mixgb with bootstrap: saving models and imputing set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4 -- 5 imputed.testdata <- impute_new(object = imputed.obj, newdata = test.data) #> Imputing new data with mixgb:  set -- 1 -- 2 -- 3 -- 4 -- 5

what: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost — mixgb-package
title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost — mixgb-package
text: Mixgb scalable multiple imputation framework based XGBoost, bootstrapping predictive mean matching. fitting XGBoost models fully conditional specification, mixgb able automatically capture complex data structure interactions non-linearity. shown framework obtains less biased estimates reflects appropriate imputation variability, achieving high computational efficiency.

title: mixgb: Multiple Imputation Through XGBoost — mixgb-package
text: Deng, Y., & Lumley, T. (2021). Multiple Imputation XGBoost. arXiv preprint arXiv:2106.01574. Chen, T., & Guestrin, C. (2016, August). Xgboost: scalable tree boosting system. Proceedings 22nd acm sigkdd international conference knowledge discovery data mining (pp. 785-794). van Buuren, S., Brand, J.P.L., Groothuis-Oudshoorn C.G.M., Rubin, D.B. (2006) Fully conditional specification multivariate imputation.  Journal Statistical Computation Simulation, 76, 12, 1049--1064. Van Buuren, S. (2018). Flexible Imputation Missing Data. Second Edition. Chapman & Hall/CRC. Boca Raton, FL.

what: Use cross-validation to find the optimal nrounds — mixgb_cv
title: Use cross-validation to find the optimal nrounds — mixgb_cv
text: Use cross-validation find optimal nrounds Mixgb imputer. Note method relies complete cases dataset find optimal nrounds. preliminary feature functions pre-tune hyperparameters development.

title: Use cross-validation to find the optimal nrounds — mixgb_cv
code: mixgb_cv(   data,   nfold = 5,   nrounds = 100,   early_stopping_rounds = 10,   response = NULL,   select_covariates = NULL,   stringsAsFactors = FALSE,   verbose = TRUE,   ... )

title: Use cross-validation to find the optimal nrounds — mixgb_cv
text: data data.frame data.table missing values. nfold number subsamples randomly partitioned equal size. Default: 5 nrounds max number iterations XGBoost training. Default: 100 early_stopping_rounds integer value k. Training stop validation performance improved k rounds. response name column index response variable. Default: NULL (Randomly select incomplete variable). select_covariates names indices selected covariates. Default: NULL (Select variables dataset). stringsAsFactors logical value indicating whether character vectors converted factors. verbose logical value. Whether print cross-validation results process. ... Extra arguments pass XGBoost.

title: Use cross-validation to find the optimal nrounds — mixgb_cv
text: list optimal nrounds evaluation.log

title: Use cross-validation to find the optimal nrounds — mixgb_cv
NHANES III (1988-1994) newborn data — nhanes3_newborn
text: dataset extracted NHANES III (1988-1994) age class Newborn (1 year). Please note example dataset contains selected variables used demonstrating use R package mixgb. information NHANES III data can found https://wwwn.cdc.gov/Nchs/Data/Nhanes3/7a/doc/mimodels.pdf

title: NHANES III (1988-1994) newborn data — nhanes3_newborn
code: data(nhanes3_newborn)

title: NHANES III (1988-1994) newborn data — nhanes3_newborn
text: data frame 2107 rows 16 variables. Nine variables missing values. HSHSIZER Household size. integer variable 1 10. HSAGEIR Age interview (screener) - qty (months). integer variable 2 11. HSSEX Sex. factor variable levels 1 (Male) 2 (Female). DMARACER Race. factor variable levels 1 (White), 2 (Black) 3 (). DMAETHNR Ethnicity. factor variable levels 1 (Mexican-American), 2 (Hispanic) 3 (Hispanic). DMARETHN Race-ethnicity. factor variable levels 1 (Non-Hispanic white), 2 (Non-Hispanic black), 3 (Mexican-American) 4 (). BMPHEAD Head circumference (cm) BMPRECUM Recumbent length (cm) BMPSB1 First subscapular skinfold (mm) BMPSB2 Second subscapular skinfold (mm) BMPTR1 First triceps skinfold (mm) BMPTR2 Second triceps skinfold (mm) BMPWT Weight (kg) DMPPIR Poverty income ratio HFF1 anyone lives smoke cigarettes home? factor variable levels 1 (Yes) 2 (). HYD1 health SP general? ordinal factor levels 1 (Excellent), 2 (good), 3 (Good), 4 (Fair) 5 (Poor).

title: NHANES III (1988-1994) newborn data — nhanes3_newborn
text: https://wwwn.cdc.gov/nchs/nhanes/nhanes3/datafiles.aspx

title: NHANES III (1988-1994) newborn data — nhanes3_newborn
text: U.S. Department Health Human Services (DHHS).  National Center Health Statistics.  Third National Health Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES III, 1988-1994): Multiply Imputed Data Set. CD-ROM, Series 11, . 7A. Hyattsville, MD: Centers Disease Control Prevention, 2001. Includes access software: Adobe Systems, Inc. Acrobat Reader version 4.
